resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: This small painting appears to be a view of a Greek or Roman temple: Gérôme discovered antique architecture during his travel to Italy in 1843.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Ewer. Copper or silver ewers were often crafted in Iran or in Egypt: with its very specific shape, this object of Gérôme own collection was used in his painting A Joke to construct the impression of an Oriental setting. Jean-Léon Gérôme, A Joke, 1882, oil on canvas (private collection).
resource.chars:
Ewer. Copper or silver ewers were often crafted in Iran or in Egypt: with its very specific shape, this object of Gérôme own collection was used in his painting A Joke to construct the impression of an Oriental setting.

Jean-Léon Gérôme, A Joke, 1882, oil on canvas (private collection).

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Jean-Léon Gérôme (1824–1904) was a French Orientalist painter and sculptor. As an academic artist, Gérôme was widely acclaimed, and maybe one of the most famous painter of his time. His work participated in the construction and the diffusion of a particular vision of Northern Africa and Asia as a fictive "Orient", a faraway land with mixed elements of various cultures. His studio, described by Gustave Goetschy as "busier and richer than an Oriental bazaar", received his many models and students. Furnished richly and decorated with his personal collection, he found in his studio the inspiration for his Orientalist paintings, but also props for models to pose with. Like his work, Gérôme's workspace was eclectic, cultivating a taste for the Orient with objects from various countries he could then use to fill his canvases. Fernand Cormon, Portrait of Gérôme in his studio, 1891, oil on canvas (France, Vesoul, Georges Garret Museum).
resource.chars:
Jean-Léon Gérôme (1824–1904) was a French Orientalist painter and sculptor. As an academic artist, Gérôme was widely acclaimed, and maybe one of the most famous painter of his time. His work participated in the construction and the diffusion of a particular vision of Northern Africa and Asia as a fictive "Orient", a faraway land with mixed elements of various cultures.

His studio, described by Gustave Goetschy as "busier and richer than an Oriental bazaar", received his many models and students. Furnished richly and decorated with his personal collection, he found in his studio the inspiration for his Orientalist paintings, but also props for models to pose with. Like his work, Gérôme's workspace was eclectic, cultivating a taste for the Orient with objects from various countries he could then use to fill his canvases.

Fernand Cormon, Portrait of Gérôme in his studio, 1891, oil on canvas (France, Vesoul, Georges Garret Museum).

item.value: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" d="M684.97226,1168.962h164.06268v0h164.06268v218.60053v218.60053h-164.06268h-164.06268v-218.60053z" data-paper-data="{"strokeWidth":1,"rotation":0,"annotation":null,"nonHoverStrokeColor":["Color",0,0.74902,1],"editable":true}" id="rectangle_5bdb05e2-5a02-4d31-a58d-a3f836580880" fill-opacity="0.00001" fill="#00bfff" fill-rule="nonzero" stroke="#00bfff" stroke-width="5" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="miter" stroke-miterlimit="10" stroke-dasharray="" stroke-dashoffset="0" font-family="none" font-weight="none" font-size="none" text-anchor="none" style="mix-blend-mode: normal"/></svg>

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Through his life, Jean-Léon Gérôme gathered a collection of weapons from various North African and Asian countries. His collection was used as props in his paintings of a phantasmagorical Orient. Jean-Léon Gérôme, A Weapons Merchant in Cairo, 1869, oil on canvas (private collection). The helmets, shields and guns depicted are all from Gérôme personal collection. Even though Gérôme tried to emulate authenticity in this depiction of the daily life in Egypt, the helmets are Indian, illustrating the generalization made about the "Orient" as an unchanging entity with no differences between cultures.
resource.chars:
Through his life, Jean-Léon Gérôme gathered a collection of weapons from various North African and Asian countries. His collection was used as props in his paintings of a phantasmagorical Orient.

Jean-Léon Gérôme, A Weapons Merchant in Cairo, 1869, oil on canvas (private collection).

The helmets, shields and guns depicted are all from Gérôme personal collection.

Even though Gérôme tried to emulate authenticity in this depiction of the daily life in Egypt, the helmets are Indian, illustrating the generalization made about the "Orient" as an unchanging entity with no differences between cultures.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Japanese armor. Despite Eastern Asia being scarcely represented in Gérôme's work, the eclecticism of his collection is characteristic of nineteenth century collectors, whose Asian and Middle Eastern objects often figured amongst larger collections of contemporary works, antique and medieval art, furnitures, etc. Gérôme still visibly took an interest in Japan: Jean-Léon Gérôme, Japanese Emploring A Deity, oil on canvas (private collection).
resource.chars:
Japanese armor. Despite Eastern Asia being scarcely represented in Gérôme's work, the eclecticism of his collection is characteristic of nineteenth century collectors, whose Asian and Middle Eastern objects often figured amongst larger collections of contemporary works, antique and medieval art, furnitures, etc.

Gérôme still visibly took an interest in Japan:

Jean-Léon Gérôme, Japanese Emploring A Deity, oil on canvas (private collection).

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Hexagonal Chinese lantern. The six sides, often in paper or glass, were decorated with characters or landscapes. Highly decorative, Chinese and Japanese objects were imported during the nineteenth century and bought by collectors, or even by amateurs to decorate their homes. Chinese lantern, 18th century, bamboo and paper (France, Le Havre Museum of Art and History).
resource.chars:
Hexagonal Chinese lantern. The six sides, often in paper or glass, were decorated with characters or landscapes. Highly decorative, Chinese and Japanese objects were imported during the nineteenth century and bought by collectors, or even by amateurs to decorate their homes.

Chinese lantern, 18th century, bamboo and paper (France, Le Havre Museum of Art and History).
